Award.AwardTitle: Constraining Continental Rifting Using a Novel Seismic Imaging Approach
Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Scott Burdick has been awarded an NSF EAR Postdoctoral fellowship to carry out a research and education plan at the University of Maryland. The investigation will focus on developing seismic images of rifting continental lithosphere and the underlying mantle in order to provide new constraints on the factors that control continental rifting. Continental rift zones, localized regions where extension occurs and the lithosphere is ruptured, play a central role in continental evolution. Despite progress in modeling of rifting lithosphere, fundamental questions concerning the initiation and evolution of continental rifts remain. The education plan will include developing teaching modules for introductory classes, and mentoring graduate and undergraduate students in developing tomographic models

To accomplish the goals of the project, Dr. Burdick will use whole-mantle traveltime tomography and a novel reflection tomography method that simultaneously constraints both smooth variations in seismic velocity and locations of seismic discontinuities, such as the lithosphere-asthenosphere boundary and mid-lithopsheric discontinuities. The proposed research is focused on two active and well-instrumented continental rifts: the Rio Grande Rift and the Salton Trough. In order to provide a point of reference on the preexisting seismic properties involved in the initiation of rifting, the project will also examine the South Georgia Suture. All study regions are covered by dense broadband seismic arrays. Data from these arrays, as well as the USArray Transportable Array and global catalogues will be used in the continental-scale research component that will help provide a connection to deeper processes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Seismic waves generated by earthquakes and recorded by seismic stations around the world provide some of the most vital insight into the deep Earth processes that drive continents together and rift them apart.  The velocity with which seismic waves travel is affected by variations in temperature, mineral composition, melt, and fluid content.  Seismic tomography is one of the best tools to interrogate these variations.  With its images of cold, seismically fast slabs descending from subduction zones and hot, buoyant plumes rising from the deep mantle, tomographic velocity models provides us with a three-dimensional snapshot of the dynamic mantle and helps us understand its relationship to the origin and evolution of the Earth’s lithosphere.

Funding from this award allowed for the construction and publication of a P-wave velocity model of North America using data from USArray, the seismological component of Earthscope.  This model brings greater illumination to large scale features in the mantle beneath the United States—failed continental rifts beneath the midcontinent and Mississippi embayment, a concentrated slow region underlying recent volcanism in central Virginia, and, for the first time, the deep structure of the Pacific plate subducted beneath Alaska and the Aleutians. 

Traditional tomography methods have difficulty estimating the uncertainty and tradeoffs in velocity values, and therefore the interpretation of tomographic models is typically qualitative in nature.  In order to test hypotheses about Earth structure, it is vital to have a quantitative understanding of the error bars on tomographic models.  For this reason, we developed a transdimensional Bayesian tomography method.  Instead of finding one single velocity model that fits the data best, a vast ensemble of models is created, and the statistics (mean, standard deviation, etc.) of the velocities that explain the data can be derived.  This novel method was applied to USArray and global seismic traveltime data to create a ensemble of models for the mantle beneath North America.  The results underscore the improvements in our understanding of the mantle due to USArray—the standard deviation of the models is reduced everywhere beneath the array, and by several times in regions like the Great Plains where little data was available prior to the Earthscope Project. 

The flexible, efficient method developed as a result of this project, though initially developed for the mantle tomography problem, has since been adapted for a wide array of Earth Science problems.  Active source seismic profiles on the Greenland Ice Sheet have been inverted to estimate the volume of glacial aquifers and its uncertainty.  Surface waves and body waves passing through the inner core have been used find the anisotropic structure of the lithosphere and uppermost inner core, respectively.  Application to raw mass spectrometer data yields improved the accuracy of error bars on rock ages in geochronology.  Developments were made on applying the methodology to scattered wave imaging with receiver functions in order to better estimate the lithospheric structure of continental rifts.

The models and algorithms created under this award have been made available to the community.  Visualizations of the methods and animations of 3-D models have been shared on social media to broaden the understanding and interest in the results.  Furthermore, special effort has been made to popularize within the seismological community the idea that uncertainty estimation in seismic tomography is vital for relating velocity to other geological and geophysical constraints on the Earth’s structure.
